body:
> In particular, it's really unfortunate that I didn't notice that Immutables was generating the implementations in the api module until now. That means far more was exposed and will break with these changes -- otherwise we could have simply made the removed methods return null or update them to return values from the ViewVersion and kept the getters. But the implementations are changing and had public builders as well.

It's a mess up on my part and I should have noticed this when `@Value.Immutable` usage was added to `iceberg-api`. I was the main driving factor to get `@Value.Immutable`  into Iceberg and it should have been my responsibility to make sure we're not exposing more than we should, especially in the `iceberg-api` module. 

I have moved the View-specific Immutable classes as part of this PR to `iceberg-core` and I also opened https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/8099 to do the same for the other places in `iceberg-api`.

Once both PRs are merged, I'll add a follow-up and mention in the docs that `@Value.Immutable` usage is discouraged on `iceberg-api` (with a checkstyle rule that enforces it) and will also remove the Immutable dependency

> I think we have very different models for skew.

Ah, yeah. I can get your point now. For your model of skewness, bucket per column vs bucket multiple columns indeed don't have a ton of difference.

When I'm modeling skewness, I am more concerning of unbalanced data partitions/buckets, consider the [Pareto_principle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pareto_principle)
Are you still working on this @rakesh-das08 ?

Interesting. I ran an experiment - spun up two side-by-side EMR clusters as a controlled test. EMR 6.10 (Spark 3.3.1, Iceberg 1.1.0) and EMR 6.11 (Spark 3.3.2, Iceberg 1.2.0).

Verified that the same operations on the `files` metadata tables do read the _same_ exact amount of input data, indicating to me that predicates are working. The same query (`SELECT * FROM <preamble>.files`) takes 2x as long on EMR 6.11 as it does on 6.10. So the warning about predicates not being pushed seems like a red herring - they _are_ being pushed, but the operation still takes longer. 

I'm now guessing that the metadata is undergoing additional processing (maybe adding `readable_metrics`?) which is causing it to take longer to get a partition's file information.
@coded9 currently I am not. Please feel free to take this up.

@rdblue any chance to review this PR? it and the related PRs were discussed on the mailing list for a while.

@wypoon it's easy to backport it to lower versions, as long as the community reaches the consensus to expose it to SQLConf

Thanks for the feedback!  Yea it sounds possible.  Is it possible to select everything but readable_metrics and see how long it takes, to verify that?

By the way, we are thinking how to fix this issue about the false warning.  cc @dramaticlly as well if you want to take a look.  Probably we can return the specs for the metadata table with the right schema.
We need to benchmark CDC read before jumping into any perf improvement. Thanks @aokolnychyi for the suggestion.
I couldn't find the place to change as well. It's in different repo? cc @nastra
https://github.com/apache/iceberg-docs/edit/main/docs/config.toml
https://github.com/apache/iceberg-docs/pull/255
Should be able to just change the table compression property and then run the rewrite datafiles command with "rewrite-all" set to true

Something like:
`actions.rewriteDataFiles()
        .filter(Expressions.equal("date", "2023-07-19"))
        .set("rewrite-all", "true")
        .execute();`

Thanks!

You mean, same amount of time as the old version, right?

By the way, the optimization that caused the false warning is:  https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/6899
Correct.  And thanks! I'm stoked to see that change

Hello @Fokko, I would like to work on this issue. I would like to confirm if I have the correct understanding. 

Does this mean that every instance of `flink-runtime` needs to be replaced with `iceberg-flink-runtime-1.16` in all over the documentation?

cc: @bitsondatadev
Superseded by newer PRs.
@ajantha-bhat I found it the day before merging the PR when I observed package collisions. I wanted to handle it in a separate PR after discussion with @nastra. Thanks for this PR.

I checked the build files again, I think we didn't miss anything and all the dependency versions are now in VersionCatalog's toml file. Also fixed a couple of small issues, hopefully tests/checks do better the next time.
+1, make sense. API module should only include interface contracts and ideally zero dependency on anything else.
Thanks for fixing this @rustyconover and @rdblue for the review!
@szehon-ho Can you take a look?

```
CREATE TABLE my_database.my_table (
    id bigint,
    title string
)
PARTITIONED BY (y string, m string, d string) 
LOCATION 's3://my-bucket/the-path-to/my_database/my_table/' 
TBLPROPERTIES (
  'table_type'='ICEBERG',
  'format'='parquet'
)
```

I failed to create nested y/m/d partition for iceberg table in Athena, how to accomplish this?
@hejiay where does the `KafkaCreateSnapshotEventToJsonListener` come from? Could you please share how you're calling `register` and the implementation of `KafkaCreateSnapshotEventToJsonListener`?
Can you add a test please to `TestListeners`
This LGTM once CI passes, @karuppayya could you rebase onto latest master please?

Thank you, the `KafkaCreateSnapshotEventToJsonListener` is my implementation of `Listener`, it sends create snapshot event to kafka topic when a snapshot was created.I register it into listeners when catalog initialize.
 And I found that when I execute the unit test `[TestFlinkHiveCatalog.testCreateCatalogWithWarehouseLocation()]`, the `HiveCatalog` would be initialized four times and the same KafkaCreateSnapshotEventToJsonListener object would be registered into the same eventType queue four times. So a snapshot event would be sent to kafka four times.
This is my calling about `register`: They are executed when `HiveCatalog` is initialized.

Could you also please share the implementation of `KafkaCreateSnapshotEventToJsonListener` if possible? I'm mainly interested whether it implements `equals()` / `hashCode()`, because most listeners won't have that implemented and so adding a `if (!listeners.contains(...))` check wouldn't really help. Here's also a short example of how listeners are registered in the tests: https://github.com/apache/iceberg/blob/96f0f22bd829a5dbe0ac8194c70a878493300b7d/api/src/test/java/org/apache/iceberg/events/TestListeners.java#L27-L28
This is my implementation of `KafkaCreateSnapshotEventToJsonListener`: And I don't overwrite `equals()` and `hashCode()`

Can someone please provide the approval for the workflow and help review this patch.
cc @pvary @Fokko @RussellSpitzer @szehon-ho @nastra
Closing this as this has been done as part of https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/7996
Closing this as this has been done as part of https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/7996

I've looked at the generated pom and I wonder whether entries for `iceberg-spark` and `iceberg-flink` should exist there? Because we typically publish those modules with a particular version, such as `iceberg-spark-3.4_2.12` or `iceberg-flink-1.17`.


Superseded by #8118.

> wonder whether entries for iceberg-spark and iceberg-flink should exist 

Nope. TBH, I just checked that the spark-x.y + flink-x.y artifacts are mentioned (those are).

Hum - realized that the Iceberg build doesn't automatically include all Scala versions. The release-process looks quite manual (`dev/stage-binaries.sh` runs the publishing tasks separately) - so the Scala 2.13 artifacts aren't included in the generated bom.
~I'm holding this one off since it depends on Python 3.8+, and we're looking for backporting 3.7 support (not a lot of success yet).~

I have updated the table property 
`
| write.parquet.compression-codec          | zstd                                               |
+------------------------------------------+----------------------------------------------------+
`

It still seems to be generating data using GZIP.

Using Spark 2.4 and Hive 3.1
2.4 is basically in maintenance only, it doesn't have the new logic present in 3.x so that would not surprise me

All checks have passed but because dependency version keep being modified there is usually a conflict with master branch, we need to sync up conflict resolution and merge when we do that or somebody else could resolve the last conflicts and merge it.
Appreciate it Russell.

Okay, so the last commit adds Scala 2.13 to the generated bom.

I tried to basically eliminate the `scalaVersion` property, but that turned out to be a huge change, so I went with the approach to "fake" all the Spark/Scala version dependencies in the bom.

Thanks very much for the pr and the fix, can you add a test ?  I have some test in https://github.com/apache/iceberg/blob/master/spark/v3.4/spark-extensions/src/test/java/org/apache/iceberg/spark/extensions/TestRewritePositionDeleteFiles.java to catch the removeDanglingDelete scenarios , I think it would fit here well.  Thanks in advance

OK, I won't notify you about version 3.1.x again, unless you re-open this PR. 😢
Moving this from "Draft" to "Ready for Review". The scope/approaches changed over the last 24 hrs, so I updated the description to reflect where this landed. 😃
Closing this one, too much effort in maintaining 3.7
@dependabot rebase
@dependabot rebase

@MaxNevermind I think, the syntax is rather self-explaining, saying "Jackson 2.13 -> requires a version >= 2.13 and < 2.14 -> prefer 2.13.4".

Overall I think that having the single version catalog is a great improvement here, especially that really all versions are managed there.

Now, let's hope that dependabot is happy with it as well.

Maybe you can push your branch to your fork's `master` branch and let dependabot run against it? Just to see whether it actually does "the right thing". I've no experience w/ dependabot and Gradle version catalogs, because we migrated to Renovate in projectnessie.
Dependabot tried to update this pull request, but something went wrong. We're looking into it, but in the meantime you can retry the update by commenting `@dependabot rebase`.

I'm getting same error . here's the exception. `updates` is the temp table created using `df.createOrReplaceTempView("updates")`

```
pyspark.sql.utils.AnalysisException: Table or view not found: updates; line 3 pos 14;
'MergeIntoTable ('dest.id = 'source.id), [insertstaraction(None)]
:- SubqueryAlias dest
:  +- SubqueryAlias iceberg_catalog.my_db.my_table
:     +- RelationV2[id#82, date#83, schema_version#86] iceberg_catalog.my_db.my_table
+- 'SubqueryAlias source
   +- 'UnresolvedRelation [updates], [], false
```

Anyone has a workaround? It actually happens on reading just a view as well within `foreachBatch` and not just with `mergeInto` sql

```
update_iceberg(df, batch_id, schema) :
    df.createOrReplaceTempView("updates_123")
    df.sparkSession.sql("select * from updates_123 limit 1").show() #fails with .AnalysisException: Table or view not found: updates_123

```


```
.foreachBatch(
            lambda df, batch_id: update_iceberg(
                df, batch_id, dest_schema_fqn
            )
        )
```
CC @coded9 @Fokko @nastra @bitsondatadev @rdblue

The problem is that you can't add data files that don't match the partitioning of the table, and this table uses a partition strategy that is not compatible with Hive (it uses hidden partitions). You should set the partitioning of the table to the same as the Hive table, then run the import.
It is awesome to get this done, @karuppayya! Thanks for reviewing, @nastra!
This issue has been closed because it has not received any activity in the last 14 days since being marked as 'stale'
cc @rdblue @RussellSpitzer @nastra @szehon-ho @flyrain @amogh-jahagirdar @singhpk234
write.orc.bloom.filter.columns can take effect on spark 3.1? when i set write.orc.bloom.filter.columns=xx, wrote data by spark and query table by xx field, but i can not find any query improvement.
when it comes to `distributed planning`, it always reminds me of [when metadata is big data](http://vldb.org/pvldb/vol14/p3083-edara.pdf), maybe that's too far.
Thanks @aokolnychyi for the awesome work. I think there are many people expect this.

@jackye1995 would you have some cycles to look into this, since you're the original author?

Hi @nastra, @Fokko, 

I have merged the changes from this pull request ( some tests changed)

https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/7996

Let me know whether I need to change anything!
@Neuw84 could you please rebase against latest master and squash all commits together?

> I was using a customized catalog that on load throws NoSuchNamespaceException when the Namespace component of a TableIdentifier is not found. Only when namespace exists, will it check the table and throws NoSuchTableException if the table is not found.

> IMO this behavior respects the Catalog.java API
https://github.com/apache/iceberg/blob/master/api/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/catalog/Catalog.java#L326

I don't think your assumption here is correct. `Catalog.loadTable()` only states `@throws NoSuchTableException if the table does not exist` and doesn't say anything about throwing a `NoSuchNamespaceException`. This is also the behavior that is implemented in [BaseMetastoreCatalog.loadTable()](https://github.com/apache/iceberg/blob/master/core/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/BaseMetastoreCatalog.java#L43-L69).

> @Neuw84 could you please rebase against latest master and squash all commits together?

Done @nastra!

@szehon-ho In order to test the case where the partition column contains ".", I changed the partition_col in the https://github.com/apache/iceberg/blob/master/spark/v3.4/spark-extensions/src/test/java/org/apache/iceberg/spark/extensions/TestRewritePositionDeleteFiles.java to partition_col.type.
Hmmm, so when the namespace is not found on ‘load(identifier)’, Catalog should still throw ‘NoSuchTable’? Isn’t that confusing? How does that help with debug?

@nastra @jackye1995 what are preconditions for merging this PR?
i hope it is just a trivial cleanup

@alesk could you please attach the stack trace to better understand where the error is coming from? In https://github.com/alesk/spark-bug-iceberg-delete I only see the error msg, but the stack trace would be quite helpful
I was mainly waiting for the original author of the code (@jackye1995) to double-check this before merging

@MaxNevermind I'm planning to do a detailed review and compare all generated artifacts. Could you please resolve the latest conflicts and squash all the commits together? Once this is done, could you please merge your changes into your [fork's](https://github.com/MaxNevermind/iceberg) master branch to see how Dependabot behaves?

Same question also asked in Slack. NoSuchTable seem to be the only allowed NOTFOUND here. 

Actually that’s not that bad in terms of clarity because I can chain the exception and still get the cause. I’ll close this.

Not every custom Iceberg catalog is required to support namespaces, that's why the `SupportsNamespaces` API exists and that's most likely the reason why `loadTable()` throws a `NoSuchTableException` rather than looking at the namespace part of the identifier

I'll use chained exception in the impl. 
Thanks for providing the context!
@karuppayya thanks for the contributions, would you mind porting these to lower spark versions? (I particularly interested in spark 3.2). Thanks

A little stranger why the CI passed with it.
CI passed due to the try-catch in the code
Ohh, I see. Thanks for the explanation.
@puchengy This cannot be ported as it is dependent on Spark changes to [support driver metrics](https://github.com/apache/spark/pull/37205), which is availble from Spark 3.4
@karuppayya Thanks for sharing! It seems to much work to first to backport spark changes to spark 3.2, make a release, and backport this change back to spark 3.2 iceberg repo.

@zinking, I know that paper and there are a few ideas in it that may be applicable to us. At the same time, Iceberg metadata already forms a system table which we query in a distributed manner (`data_files`, etc), it is similar to having a separate table for metadata. If I remember correctly, one benefit of BigQuery is that it does not have to bring back the results while doing this distributed planning but that's on Spark side to provide that functionality. In my view, it is less likely one would query 20 PB of data in a single job and when that happens, it is unlikely to be a problem to spend 30 seconds planning the job.

At this point, we are not storing large blobs in the manifests so we will come back to that paper while discussing how to support secondary indexes and how to integrate that into planning. That would be the point when the metadata would be too big. Right now, we are talking about 2-4 GB of metadata to cover 20-40 PB of data.

i ran rewriteDataFiles/compaction from spark , it created big files and left small files. I ran expireSnapShot older than x hours. Then i ran deleteOrphanFiles which have cleaned up all small files and its respective manifest list & manifest files.

try compaction -> expireSnapshots -> deleteOrphanFiles.

Even adding the bundled Guava manually to the Intellij classpath doesn't help. After adding manually to the classpath in Intellij: We get errors like this: This is rather odd, since now it complains that it cannot find `Maps` but manages to resolve the package! Perhaps in Intellij issue (with Gradle integration). What do other committers use as their IDE?

The suggested fixes do not seem to work with recent versions of Intellij. Tried the approaches suggested, but Intellij just refuses to locate the dependency Really odd, since the Intellij Gradle settings do show up the `iceberg-bundled-guava` as a dependency, but I guess it is failing to actually locate where the built jar is or maybe something else entirely is now broken in Intellij and its Gradle integration.
